head.title: World Briefing | Environment: New Rice-Growing Technique Reduces Methane

hedline.hl1: World Briefing | Environment: New Rice-Growing Technique Reduces Methane

abstract.p: Over past two decades Chinese farmers have changed system of growing rice resulting in 40% reduction in methane emissions; methane, although not most prolific of heat-trapping gases, is 21 times more vigorous than carbon dioxide in trapping sun's heat; new method of draining rice fields several times a year not only slows atmospheric effects, but also gleans larger harvests and conserves water (S)

block.p: A shift over the past 20 years in the way rice is cultivated has reduced emissions of methane, an important heat-trapping greenhouse gas, and may account for a slowdown in the growth rate of atmospheric concentrations. Methane is much scarcer than carbon dioxide, the dominant greenhouse gas, but is 21 times more effective at trapping the sun's heat. To save water and increase yields, Chinese farmers have switched to draining fields several times a year instead of keeping them flooded. The practice appears to have reduced the activity of soil bacteria that release methane, and emissions have dropped 40 percent.
